title: Special report: 'Didn't Southampton have a responsibility to us? They let us down'
text:
The times might have been different but right and wrong doesn’t change.” And for Dave Merrington, the events of 30 years ago remain etched in his mind with the same clarity that characterised an instinct to not look the other way but to act.

As history has since proven across many areas of society, it was a tragically uncommon reaction.

The catalyst had been a minibus journey one evening in February 1989 with a group of Southampton apprentices. Merrington, who was managing the youth team, was driving home boys who had come through a schoolboy system Bob Higgins had turned into a personal kingdom.

“They were talking – banter – but of a sexual nature and it disturbed me,” he says. “I said, ‘You are talking about a member of staff here’. It went quiet. I knew there was something wrong.”

Merrington went to first-team manager Chris Nicholl, who reported the matter to directors which included two solicitors. Nicholl also felt Higgins should be informed. “I thought he would do it or the chairman,” says Merrington, “but he said, ‘I think it should be you, Dave’. I arranged a meeting in the players’ lounge. I said, ‘Look, Bob, I’m very disturbed with what I heard. Sexual allegations’. He got very aggressive. Jumped up, made a move towards me. He started pointing and saying, ‘I’ll sue anybody who says anything about me’. Within about a week he had resigned and gone.”
description: The times might have been different but right and wrong doesn’t change.
